help detect and compare vibrations

grass to solve their business challenges
and the use case has continued to grow
Nokia for example saw a need in the

processed and filtered data to remote

set up locally to process the data
locally let's take a closer look at AWS
green grass which seamlessly extends AWS
to the devices so they can act locally
on the data
generate while still using the cloud for
management analytics and durable storage
most IOT data never reaches the cloud
primarily for three reasons first is the
law of physics latency and last mile
connectivity latency of sending data
packets the cloud and getting a response
back can be unacceptable for scenarios
that involve timely automated
decision-making for example crash
avoidance and medical alerts or
equipment that is operating in remote
environments for example mining sites or
in-flight aircrafts or ships that are at
sea some decision-making such as high
value safety critical processes must
continue to operate autonomously when
internet connection is not available AWS
green grass provides tools for
communication among cooperative devices
that are interconnected over local
networks and capability to execute
application code on these remote devices
enabling you to create autonomous
applications secondly there is the law
of economics the cost of bandwidth is
not falling as fast as cost of storage
and compute AWS Greengrass provides
tools for locally aggregating and
filtering data making it easy to act on
lower value data locally and upload to
the cloud only the high value aggregated
data for analytics and storage the third
set of challenges is compliance and
privacy for legal or compliance reasons
and concerns around privacy some
industries prefer to store or duplicate
data locally for example hospitals may
be required to keep all the records
locally even if they are also duplicated
in the cloud some governments impose
data sovereignty restrictions on where
data may be stored in 2016 when we
introduced
Greengrass we launched it with the
following features local actions and
local triggers to enable a local and
symbol of IOT devices to coordinate and
operate autonomously data and states
sync capability allowed Greengrass
devices to synchronize their data and
their state with the cloud whenever
Internet connectivity is available and
we brought the security model that we
have in the AWS IOT cloud service to the
edge of the network by enabling
Greengrass to identify authenticate and
communicate with other local devices
securely by acting as the local
certificate authority we have continued
to evolve the service and as you can see
today we have much more green grass now
has complete over-the-air update
capability which allows you to remotely
update not only the data or state or
lambda functions running on your devices
but also the green grass software
package itself we have implemented a
protocol adapter for OPC UA which is a
very common protocol used in industrial
IOT the local resource access feature
makes it possible for your application
code running on green grass to take
advantage of resources like GPUs cameras
and various sensors and actuators that
might be available on the devices
locally and we have also introduced a
powerful new feature called machine
learning inference or ml inference for
short it's a mechanism for you to train
machine learning models in the cloud and
deployed them to run on green grass
devices at the edge to process the data
and take actions autonomously you might
ask what can you do with machine
learning at the edge it's really up to
your imagination
AWS green grass ml inference enables
several use cases I would like to
highlight just a few of them think about
agricultural company
during harvest they could apply machine
learning to quicksort different produce
and different quality of produce at the
farm where it is being harvested rather

and sorting it there in industrial
environments you could apply machine

how do you make this system intelligent
if you were to do machine learning today
you would start by building and training

will also run inference and predictions
in the cloud largely much of the machine
learning you see today it's done through

there are challenges associated with

green rose and machine learning the
first part the building and training of
machine learning models which is a
computer intensive job you will still do

however you deploy the trained machine

at the edge then whether the device is
connected connected to the internet or
not the device can run inference on top

can take actions locally Greenglass ml
inference relies on deeper feature of
green grass which is now also available
for all developers is called local
resource access local resource access
lets you extend the common programming
model of green grass that is the lambda
functions that you deploy on green grass
devices and lets them interact with the
underlying capabilities of the green
grass host device for example a GPU a
sensor an actuator or a bus and in this
way the lambda functions that are
written in the cloud and deployed down
to the green grass devices can start to
interact with the devices and the
physical environment around them so now
for example if I'm deploying machine
learning models on devices I can
accelerate my predictive models by
taking advantage of the GPU capabilities
of the device another feature of green
rose is its support for an industrial
messaging protocol called OPC UA OPC UA
is a popular exchange protocol that is
used in factories transportation
logistics and more it defines the way
that devices in for example a factory
are meant to interact with one another
if you you if you want to use green
drawers in an industrial environment you
would want green grass to interact with
other devices that are already deployed
in that environment and already speaking
whatever protocol it is that they are
speaking an OPC UA is a very popular one
so with the new OPC UA adapter for green
grass green grass can interact with
existing fleets of devices that speak
that protocol and also the new devices
that you might deploy they can do it in
a way that is highly secure with
certificate based mutual authentication
between green grass and the local OPC UA
server and the implementation of OPC UA
that we provide is fully customizable by
you because we've learned
enterprises and developers who use
protocols like OPC UA they get very
particular about how its configured
speaking of manufacturing and industrial

4.0 is driving a number of initiatives

prediction and preventive maintenance
these initiatives underscore the need to
bring large fleets of interoperable
devices under a single ecosystem of
cooperating devices that represents a
big challenge in its own because most in
in most cases industrial environments
are brownfield environments with a lot
of legacy equipment that is difficult to
replace these devices often speak many
different protocols but the predominant
protocol is OPC UA Greengrass with its
support for OPC UA can be used to create
this single ecosystem to enable
cooperation between existing and new
devices also the local resource access
feature of Greengrass can be leveraged
to implement Additional Protocol
adapters for devices that do not speak
OPC UA a number of opportunities open up
when you have a single ecosystem of
cooperating devices at the very minimum
it makes it possible for to implement
real-time monitoring which provides

they need to make data-driven decisions
it also becomes possible to use the IOT

what will happen in the future and we

it's really exciting we are seeing three

Greengrass applications written in the
